notes.title: Glorious Revolution (1688–89): Causes, Course, Consequences
notes.content: Why 1688 is treated as a constitutional watershed: deposition of James II, invitation to William & Mary, the Bill of Rights (1689), and the shift toward parliamentary sovereignty; use for 'significance' and 'turning point' questions (2001–2005, 2009–2013, 2019–2024).
keyTakeaways: Frame as settlement limiting royal prerogative + enhancing parliamentary authority.
Connect to Toleration Act (limits), Mutiny Act (army under Parliament), financial control.
Compare with 1832 Reform Act in 'long road to democracy' essays.

notes.title: Hanoverian Succession & Whig Ascendancy (1714–1760)
notes.content: Accession of George I (1714) → long Whig dominance; cabinet government, Walpole as de facto first PM; party system consolidation; exam emphasis on constitutional impact and George III's challenge later.
keyTakeaways: Explain why limited monarchy + cabinet responsibility grew under Hanoverians.
Use Walpole's management of Commons as institutional precedent.
Bridge to George III's 'personal rule' debates.

notes.title: Reform Act 1832 ('Great Reform') & Democratization
notes.content: Causes (rotten boroughs, industrial towns, political crisis), contents (redistribution, franchise expansion), and consequences (not full democracy, but crucial step). Use in 1832–1928 reform trajectories.
keyTakeaways: Cite mechanics: borough disfranchisement + county/borough redistribution.
Argue 'beginning of modern politics' yet still property-weighted.
Link to Chartism as response to limited scope.

resources.title: National Archives — What caused the 1832 Reform Act?

notes.title: Chartism (1838–48): A Mass Movement for Democracy
notes.content: People's Charter's Six Points; petitions (1839/1842/1848); regional diversity; reasons for failure/success in long term (agenda later achieved). Frequently paired with 1832.
keyTakeaways: Treat as working-class political mobilization & political education.
Use petitions + mass meetings + moral vs. physical force split.
Outcome: immediate failure, long-term constitutional legacy.

notes.title: Industrial Revolution: Origins, Phases & Social Impact
notes.content: Britain's industrial takeoff: textiles, steam, iron; urbanization; class formation; debates on dating & 'early' proto-industrialization. Use for 2009–2018 question clusters.
keyTakeaways: Combine classic 1760–1830 view with newer work on 17th-century shifts.
Always include social costs (housing, public health, labour) and state responses.
Tie to 1832 and later reforms; link to global consequences.

resources.title: The Guardian — New research on earlier dating (2024)

notes.title: Corn Laws & Repeal (1846): Peel, Famine & Party Split
notes.content: Tariff protection for grain vs. free trade; Anti-Corn Law League pressure; Irish Famine urgency; Peel's 1846 repeal and Conservative split. Often linked to economic liberalism.
keyTakeaways: Use petitions + public agitation evidence.
Explain humanitarian + economic rationale.
Note party realignment as political consequence.

notes.title: Gladstone vs. Disraeli: Ideologies, Reforms & Empire
notes.content: Classic compare/contrast: Gladstonian liberalism (retrenchment, moral foreign policy, Irish Home Rule attempts) vs. Disraelian conservatism (imperial assertiveness, social reform 1875, 'One Nation').
keyTakeaways: Set up a matrix: finance/church/education/Ireland/foreign policy.
Use 1867 Reform Act (Disraeli's role) and Irish Church Act 1869 (Gladstone).
Close with historiography (e.g., 'Punch' cartoons, later reassessments).

resources.title: Cambridge — Historiography of Gladstone & Disraeli (overview pages)
Gladstone's Library — Rivalry as told by Punch

notes.title: French Revolution's Impact on Britain
notes.content: Ideological shock; Pitt's repression (sedition laws), loyalist vs. radical societies; war with France; cultural anxieties. Often asked as 'panic in England' or 'influence' essays.
keyTakeaways: Balance political repression with reform currents (abolitionism, rights talk).
Use loyalist iconography & spy networks as evidence.
Tie to long-run reform debates culminating in 1832.

resources.title: UK Parliament Learning — FR impact (general parliamentary context)

notes.title: Napoleonic Wars & Waterloo: Britain's Role
notes.content: Naval supremacy (Trafalgar), coalition diplomacy, Wellington in Iberia & Waterloo (1815); post-war settlement; link to Britain's 19th-century global position.
keyTakeaways: Use 'Pitt system' of coalitions; finance & navy as decisive advantages.
Connect to Congress of Vienna & Concert of Europe.
Show continuity into 'Splendid Isolation' debates.

notes.title: Crimean War (1853–56) & the Eastern Question
notes.content: Anglo-French-Ottoman-Sardinian war vs. Russia; logistics failures, nursing reforms (Nightingale), diplomacy (Treaty of Paris); repeatedly appears with 'Eastern Question'.
keyTakeaways: Balance battlefield narrative with home-front press/public opinion.
Explain strategic aim: check Russian expansion; Ottoman integrity.
Note military/administrative reforms post-war.

resources.title: National Army Museum — Crimean War overview

notes.title: American War of Independence: Causes & British Policy
notes.content: Imperial overstretch, taxation without representation, colonial politics; British strategic errors; post-1783 policy reset and imperial re-orientation.
keyTakeaways: Use fiscal-military state framework; global context (France/Spain).
Show lessons influencing 19th-century imperial governance.
Bridge to Canada/Australia & later 'Dominion' model.

resources.title: UK National Archives — American Revolution collections

notes.title: Unions: 1707 (England–Scotland) & 1801 (Great Britain–Ireland)
notes.content: Compare political contexts, motives (security, trade, confessional politics), structures created, and long-term consequences; appears as compare/contrast prompts.
keyTakeaways: 1707: integrate parliaments; 1801: incorporate Ireland amid rebellion/war.
Assess representation, religion (Catholic emancipation delays), and economies.
Link to Irish Question, Home Rule, partition.

notes.title: Victorian Society: Religion, Reform & Social Policy
notes.content: Poor Law (1834), factory acts, public health; Nonconformity; education; philanthropy. Useful to integrate with industrial impacts and party politics.
keyTakeaways: Argue 'reforming state' emergence with data points (acts & commissions).
Contrast moralism vs. utilitarianism in policy design.
Tie to Disraeli's 1875 social reforms & Gladstone's civil reforms.

notes.title: MacBride Commission & Global News Flows (context tool)
notes.content: Though global, useful for 'news imbalance' and Britain's media diplomacy angles in modern essays (pairs with BBC World Service, decolonization narratives).
keyTakeaways: Use sparingly to enrich modern media/power essays.
Connect to post-imperial soft power discussions.

notes.title: World War I: Causes, Course & Effects on Britain
notes.content: Alliance system, militarism, imperial rivalries; total war at home (DORA, conscription, women's work); post-war political & social change.
keyTakeaways: Weave European causes with British domestic transformation.
Include losses, debt, and Irish dimension (Easter Rising context).
Mention 1918 Representation of the People Act link to suffrage.

resources.title: British Library — WWI resources blog hub

notes.title: World War II & Post-War Settlement (brief exam frame)
notes.content: Strategic leadership (Churchill), total war mobilization, 1945 Labour landslide; welfare state (Beveridge), NHS; early Cold War positioning.
keyTakeaways: Use to bridge 1930s appeasement debates to post-war social reforms.
Connect to decolonization pressures post-1945.
Drop precise policy examples (NHS 1948) for scoring.

notes.title: Suez Crisis (1956): Decline of Great-Power Pretensions
notes.content: Nationalization by Nasser; Anglo-French-Israeli operation; US/Soviet pressure; withdrawal; constitutional + diplomatic lessons; a top recurrent post-1945 topic.
keyTakeaways: Use Hansard extracts for contemporary British positions.
Argue Suez as inflection point in post-imperial foreign policy.
Tie to 'special relationship' recalibration & UN diplomacy.

resources.title: GWU National Security Archive — Suez dossier

notes.title: Falklands War (1982): Causes, Course & Consequences
notes.content: Argentine invasion; UK Task Force; diplomacy & combat; domestic political effects; Latin America relations; frequent recent exam appearance.
keyTakeaways: Add operation name (Corporate) and outcome; dates & islands' status.
Discuss media, public opinion, and defence doctrine implications.
Situate in late-Cold War context.

resources.title: National Archives Blog — Researching Op Corporate

notes.title: British Commonwealth vs. Empire
notes.content: Define 'Empire' (coercive/colonial governance) vs. 'Commonwealth' (voluntary association); transitions: Statute of Westminster (1931), dominion status; post-1945 decolonization.
keyTakeaways: Use specific dominion examples (Canada/Australia/NZ) for chronology.
Link to India/Pakistan independence and later Commonwealth roles.
Good for compare/contrast and 'continuity/change' essays.

notes.title: Labour & Conservative Parties (20th Century): Programmes & Turning Points
notes.content: Labour 1945–51 (welfare/NHS/nationalization); Conservative post-1951 mixed economy; monetarism & Thatcherism; New Labour (1997–2007).
keyTakeaways: Use 'Butskellism' shorthand for 1950s consensus.
For Thatcherism: privatization, deregulation, union reform; for Blair: devolution, constitutional reform, Iraq War context.
Cite one policy per era for precision.

notes.title: Eastern Question to Splendid Isolation (and its Abandonment)
notes.content: Use as a foreign-policy arc: managing Ottoman decline (Crimea); late-19th-century isolation; 1904 Entente Cordiale; 1907 Anglo-Russian Convention; path to WWI.
keyTakeaways: Define 'Splendid Isolation' precisely and give end-date markers (1902–1907).
Connect to balance-of-power strategy & naval priorities.
Pair with Crimean War and Boer War as pressure points.

resources.title: UK Parliament — Chartist & elections pages (for context of domestic constraints)

notes.title: Ireland: Home Rule, Partition & The Troubles (exam capsule)
notes.content: From Union (1801) to Home Rule crises, 1916, partition (1921), and late-20th-century Troubles; use for 'Irish Question' and Liberal Party essays.
keyTakeaways: Show Liberal splits over Home Rule (Gladstone).
Mark 1921 Anglo-Irish Treaty as a constitutional watershed.
For modern: Good Friday Agreement (1998) as closure point.

notes.title: Methodist & Religious Revivals; Social Movements
notes.content: Wesleyan/Methodist revival's social effects; temperance; abolitionism; women's movements; link to working-class organization and political reform.
keyTakeaways: Use as cultural/ethical counterweight to industrialization problems.
Connect to literacy, associational life, and political education.
Good for 19th-century society essays.

resources.title: British Library — Religion in Victorian Britain

notes.title: WWI/WWII → Decolonization: Why Britain Withdrew
notes.content: Costs of world wars, nationalist movements, changing global norms, US/UN pressure, Cold War calculus; use India/Pakistan 1947 as core case.
keyTakeaways: Combine structural (fiscal/strategic) with agency (colonial movements).
Highlight 1947 as hinge; then Africa/Asia waves.
End with Commonwealth framework.

notes.title: Exam Skills: Comparative Frames & Primary Evidence
notes.content: For repeated questions (Glorious Revolution, 1832, Chartism, Peel/Gladstone/Disraeli, Suez, Falklands): prepare 10–12 sentence 'mini-skeletons' with 3 citations each (Parliament/NA/BL).
keyTakeaways: Open with a precise thesis; end with historiography or continuity/rupture line.
Always date Acts/treaties; quote one primary line if possible (Hansard/Acts).
Use 2–3 compare/contrast matrices (e.g., Gladstone vs. Disraeli; 1832 vs. 1867).

notes.title: MCQ Staples: Dates, Acts, Acronyms & Who's Who
notes.content: A ready-to-drill list: 1688 (Glorious Revolution); 1707/1801 (Unions); 1832/1867 (Reform Acts); 1846 (Corn Law repeal); 1854–56 (Crimea); 1914–18/1939–45 (World Wars); 1956 (Suez); 1982 (Falklands). Pair with key figures: Walpole, Pitt(s), Peel, Gladstone, Disraeli, Palmerston, Churchill, Thatcher.
keyTakeaways: Memorize 1–line definitions: 'Splendid Isolation', 'Entente Cordiale'.
Know core treaty names: Utrecht (1713), Paris (1763/1783), Vienna (1815), Versailles (1919).
Link each act/treaty to 1 consequence for rapid MCQ elimination.
